title: Behavioral Economics and Decision Making
description: Behavioral economics studies how psychological, cognitive, and emotional factors affect economic decisions, providing insights into real human behavior.
learning_objectives: Understand deviations from rational choice theory
Recognize common cognitive biases in decision making
Apply behavioral economics to Active Inference
Design choice architectures that account for human behavior

content.overview: Behavioral economics bridges psychology and economics, showing that human decision making systematically deviates from the rational choice model. It provides realistic models of how people actually make decisions under uncertainty, with direct applications to Active Inference.

foundational_concepts.dual_system_theory: Fast intuitive vs slow deliberative thinking

key_behavioral_principles.loss_aversion: Losses loom larger than equivalent gains
key_behavioral_principles.reference_dependence: Outcomes evaluated relative to reference point

connection_to_active_inference.bounded_rationality: Active Inference naturally models limited cognition
connection_to_active_inference.expected_free_energy: Behavioral economics as minimizing free energy
connection_to_active_inference.policy_selection: Biased decision making as bounded optimization

decision_making_under_uncertainty.ambiguity_aversion: Preference for known over unknown probabilities

applications.policy_design: Design policies that work with human behavior

examples.name: Loss Aversion in Investment
examples.description: People hold losing investments too long
examples.active_inference: Belief updating resistant to contradictory evidence
examples.implication: Design interventions that reset reference points

examples.name: Default Options
examples.mechanism: Status quo bias and decision avoidance

nudging_and_choice_architecture.choice_architecture: How choices are presented affects decisions

criticisms_and_limitations.predictive_power: Behavioral models may lack predictive accuracy
criticisms_and_limitations.intervention_effectiveness: Nudges may lose effectiveness over time

interactive_exercises.description: Identify cognitive biases in decision scenarios
Model decisions using prospect theory value function

common_misconceptions.misconception: Behavioral economics shows humans are irrational
common_misconceptions.clarification: Humans are rational but with different goals and constraints
Biases can be adaptive in certain environments
Nudging works with human psychology to achieve mutual benefits
